text: I sometimes get asked about an
anti-science mentality and I think there
is an anti-science mentality in in the
Islamic world not universal by any means
in fact Glennis and I both know a great
Pakistani physicist abdus salam but
widespread abdus tried very hard to get
the oil-rich countries of the Gulf the
Persian Gulf to put money into science
education and he sounds very hard that
they were willing to have engineering
education but they didn't want to get
into into pure science because they felt
that was disruptive and this is a view
that goes back to the 12th century the
Muslim Brotherhood at one point
advocated giving up scientific education
in Egyptian schools but in in the West I
don't find an anti-science mentality
what I find is a confusion about what
science is I testified in the Texas
Board of Education hearing some years
ago and I the all the members of the
board they were discussing the issue of
whether or not to have teaching of
creationism in the schools yeah this is
a perennial issue and they did not say
as an antidote for science but they
thought real scientific training should
teach you to be willing to consider
different hypotheses and which something
that I can't disagree with although you
know we don't have our students study
alternate theories of the shape of the
earth like the Flat Earth theory and the
around Earth theory because that's
pretty well settled and if students are
going to study things that are
controversial they really should be
controversial which evolution is not at
least within the scientific community so
but they were not anti-science they were
just confused about what science was I
think that's really the problem
